Excellent question! Silver-plated and sterling silver are two different types of silver finishes, and they can significantly impact the quality and appearance of the jewelry.

**Silver-plated:**

* A thin layer of silver is deposited onto a base metal (usually copper or zinc) using an electroplating process.
* The silver layer is relatively thin, often only 0.05% to 0.5% of the total metal thickness.
* Silver-plated jewelry can be more prone to tarnishing and wear off over time, exposing the base metal underneath.
* Generally less expensive than sterling silver.

**Sterling Silver:**

* An alloy of 92.5% silver and 7.5% other metals (usually copper).
* The silver content is much higher than silver-plated, making it more durable and resistant to tarnish.
* Sterling silver is often stamped with a "925" hallmark to indicate its authenticity.
* More expensive than silver-plated, but still relatively affordable.

Sterling silver is generally considered a higher-quality and more durable option than silver-plated. It's less likely to tarnish or wear off, and it has a brighter, more luxurious appearance. If you want a piece that will last and look great for years to come, sterling silver is a good choice.

That being said, silver-plated jewelry can still be a good option if you're on a tight budget or looking for a trendy, fashion-forward piece. Just be aware that it may not be as durable or long-lasting as sterling silver.

For a $50 budget, you can find some nice sterling silver pieces, especially if you look for simpler designs or smaller items like earrings or charms. If you're willing to compromise on the metal quality, you can also find some beautiful silver-plated pieces that still look great.

Do you have a preference for sterling silver or are you open to considering silver-plated options as well?
